item.title: Report E-2023120319
item.description:
Report E-2023120319

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-22T18:12:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-19
  • City: WICHITA
  • State: KS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XWK experienced a UN1791 Extract 2 release from (4) 55-gallon poly drums. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of product released to the drum lids and a 4’ x 4’ area of the trailer floor and cardboard. The bung caps were replaced on all four drums, and they were decontaminated and secured for shipment on. Vinegar solution was used to neutralize the released product. The impacted cardboard and rags were then containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report I-2023120029
item.description:
Report I-2023120029

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-22T18:12:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-05
  • City: Weldon
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: SOUTHEASTERN FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Shipment of 1 15 gallon drum that had been secured(strapped) to the left side wall of trailer at the rear. The container split on side while in transit on a Pick up and Delivery route. The drum was strapped and there was no other freight around the container. The driver noticed the material leaking upon arrival to the another delivery before the destination of the is shipment. The contents of the container and the leaking container were both handled by an environmental clean up contractor and removed from the location for disposal by the contractor as well.

item.title: Report X-2023120304
item.description:
Report X-2023120304

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-22T18:12:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-01
  • City: OLATHE
  • State: KS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found by Eastside unload manager as soon as he lifted the door to trailer 18289. package was not secured or braced. it was in the middle of floor by itself. the trailer was not all the way full. there was a good 10 or so feet for the package to tumble while in transportation. package was leaking in the middle of the open space. As soon as it was found, QA was called to start processing DescribePack: one cap came loose off of a 1 gallon bottle. package was nor braced or secured in trailer and looked to have moved around while in transit. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: QA was called as soon as it was found. Package was far enough away from other packages in trailer that none were effected by it.

item.title: Report X-2023120299
item.description:
Report X-2023120299

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-22T18:12:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-01
  • City: ELLENWOOD
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was taken to the Hazmat area and QA was informed to address the package. DescribePack: The top was loose on the bottle and there was no seal on the bottle to prevent any spillage. DurationRel: 5 and MitigateEffect: The package was load right side up to prevent any more leakage.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 11, 2023, four (4) one-gallon containers of paint were crushed in transit and released approximately four (4) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel collected four (4) damaged 1-gallon containers of paint (UN1263) and containerized them in one (1) 55-gallon drum as waste. HCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted surfaces of the trailer and worked them in with hand tools. All paint (UN1263) -impacted material was collected and containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums that were staged on-site in RLC's consolidated waste area.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: On December 06, 2023, at 2020 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Carthage, Texas regarding the release of approximately (15) gallons of UN 2873, Dibutylaminoethanol, 6.1, PG III from a (1) 55-gallon DM that was punctured caused by a load shift. Contractors confirmed the release was contained to a 10’ x 8’ area on the trailer floor, a 4’ x 4’ area of concrete under the trailer, and a 90’ x 3’ area of concrete at a fuel island. The release was cleaned using bleach and absorbents while wearing the proper PPE. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (3) 55-gallon DM’s and 1 supersack, which was then taken offsite by the contractor for proper disposal.

  • Description: On December 11, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN3266 was overfilled and released approximately twelve (12) ounces of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. The bung lid was inspected and resecured with a new lid for continued processing and shipping. Cleaners and absorbent pads were utilized to remove any residual product. All UN3266 impacted materials and spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) five-gallon pail for disposal. The pail was properly labeled, and possession of the material was taken by RLC to be disposed of through their bulk waste stream.

  • Description: On the afternoon of 12/08/23 at 13:56, a team of drivers attempted an offload at the facility in Garyville, LA.  During the initial leak check, there were vapors visible from the nitrogen plug. Instructions given to tighten the plug, was attempted and were able to tighten by one full turn of the plug. Leak path still existed. Manager consulted with Tech Services, HF Operations and Dangerous Goods.  Decided to involve third-party emergency response company to evaluate and remedy the situation to make the tanker road worthy for the trip back to origin site.

UN1760, 8, PG II) from (6) 5-gallon poly pails. Contractors confirmed the release was caused by a load shift from the absence of proper dunnage securing the load, and was contained to a 4’ x 8’ area on the trailer floor. Contractors neutralized and cleaned the release with the proper PPE, and the cargo was then properly secured for transport. The damaged pails containing “materials for reprocessing” were placed in (2) 55-gallon DM’s, which were then taken offsite by the contractor for proper processing.

  • Description: 1. X-2023120326 SequenceEvent: SEQUENCE OF EVENTS UNKNOWN. AT TIME OF DISCOVERY, PACKAGE WAS TAKEN TO HAZMAT CAGE. AT THAT TIME THE PACKAGE WAS PLACED IN HAZBAG AND PLACED IN HAZMAT TOTE. DescribePack: TWO OF THE FOUR CANS WERE DENTED AND CONTENTS LEAKED OUT OF PENCIL-TIP SIZED HOLE WHERE THE METAL WAS BENT. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: METAL JERRICANS WERE UP-RIGHTED BECAUSE THE CONTENTS HAD ALREADY LEAKED OUT BEYOND WHERE THE DAMAGED HOLE WAS LOCATED, WHICH WAS TOWARD THE TOP PART OF THE CONTAINER. 2. X-2023120330 SequenceEvent: SEQUENCE OF EVENTS UNKNOWN. AT TIME OF DISCOVERY, PACKAGE WAS TAKEN TO HAZMAT CAGE. AT THAT TIME THE PACKAGE WAS PLACED IN HAZBAG AND PLACED IN HAZMAT TOTE. DescribePack: TWO OF THE FOUR CANS WERE DENTED AND CONTENTS LEAKED OUT OF HOLE WHERE THE METAL WAS BENT ON ONE OF THE CONTAINERS AND FROM THE LOOSENED CAP ON THE OTHER. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: BECAUSE THE CONTENTS HAD ALREADY LEAKED OUT BEYOND WHERE THE DAMAGED HOLE WAS LOCATED, THE METAL CANS WERE UP-RIGHTED TO PREVENT ANY FURTHER LEAKING.

  • City: FRANKFORT
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 8, 2023, twenty (20) one-gallon pails of paint were crushed in transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the paint-impacted trailer interior and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums and all boxes and containers were placed into two (2) 55-gallon drums. All drums were staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 8, 2023, one (1) 2.5 gallon jug of ZeroTol 2.0 was crushed in transit and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Ten West Environmental (TWE) to remediate the impacted site. TWE personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and soda ash to remediate the ZeroTol-impacted impacted trailer. The crew de palletized, re palletized, and shrink wrapped the freight for the customer. TWE personnel solidified and neutralized the damaged jug of product. The damaged jug and all impacted debris were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon poly vented drums and stored on site for transport and disposal.

  • Description: On December 8, 2023, one (1) one-gallon glass jar containing sulfuric acid (UN1830) was damaged by a forklift and released its full contents to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Marion Environmental Services (MES) to remediate the impacted site. MES personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and soda ash to remediate the sulfuric acid-impacted impacted dock and pallet. The crew down stacked the pallet, re packaged, and secured cleaned freight to be shipped. MES personnel solidified and neutralized the damaged glass jar of sulfuric acid. The damaged glass jar, impacted absorbents and cardboard box were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum that was staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LLB experienced a NA1993 CORR21334A release from a 230-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of material released to a 2’ x 2’ area of the trailer floor and a 1’ x 1’ area of the concrete dock due to a bad valve. The product was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with impacted absorbents and PPE into (2) 55-gallon metal drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: 1. X-2023120366 SequenceEvent: Pkg. received from driver after they noticed pkg. was wet, pkg. received from 389-OLIV-A. Pkg. taken to QA for further inspection. DescribePack: It was noted after inspecting contents, one of the containers had a loose cap, causing liquid to leak out. The shipper does not provide protective material inside box to protect the caps if the pkg. is dropped. This is not the first time we have encounter damages on these items, same shipper. Orientation arrows on pkg. DurationRel: 5 and MitigateEffect: Pkg. sitting in the HMPA awaiting instructions from PGH. 2. X-2023120368 SequenceEvent: Pkg. was remove from van after it was noted by loader, that pkg. was wet. Pkg. taken to QA for further inspection. DescribePack: Upon inspecting contents, it was noted that 1 of the containers had a loose cap, causing liquid to leak out. There were no protective material in box to protect caps. Orientation arrows present. DurationRel: 5 and MitigateEffect: Pkg. siting in the HMPA awaiting instructions from PGH. 3. X-2023120369 SequenceEvent: Pkg. received off trailer 821657, wet, pkg. found lying on its side. Pkg. taken to QA for further inspection. DescribePack: It was noted that 2 containers had loose caps causing liquid to leak out. There was no protective material in pkg. to protect the caps. Orientation arrows present on side of box. DurationRel: 5 and MitigateEffect: Pkg. sitting in the HMPA awaiting instructions from PGH. 4. X-2023120370 SequenceEvent: pkg. received off trailer 821657, wet. Pkg. taken to QA for further inspection. DescribePack: Upon inspecting contents, it was note that both containers had loose caps, causing liquid to leak out from each. There were no protective material inside both pkgs. Orientation arrows present on side of pkg. DurationRel: 5 and MitigateEffect: pkg. sitting in HMPA awaiting further inspection from PGH.

item.description:
Report X-2023120685

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-18T21:10:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-11
  • City: LAKE ORION
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The driver that had this package on his truck was out delivering when he discovered the leaking hazmat. He put the package in plastic bags to try to contain the spill. He promptly drove to back to the Fedex Ground station and alerted QA of the package. The driver pulled the package out causing some to spill on a few other packages in the truck. He set the package on the passenger side steps while QA investigated. One QA person called the emergency number who stated they could someone out to clean up or we could clean up if we felt we could handle it. QA placed the package in a red hazmat tote. QA sprinkled the area with neutralizing powder as a safety measure. The spill was soaked up and the clean up materials placed in the salvage drum. DescribePack: The top of the cap on the bottle has broken off. DurationRel: 3 and MitigateEffect: Package was placed in a lined red hazmat tote and put into a well ventilated area. Absorbent pads were placed on the area of the spill that appeared to be dry already. We sprinkled neutralizing powder on the area just in case. The steps of the truck where the hazmat had been placed were wet so we sprinkled the neutralizing powder there as well.

DescribePack: On inspection, 4 4 liter glass jugs were found, 1 of which had no lid in place. Visual inspection determined that approximately .5 liters had leaked out of the jug and into the box, soaking into the corrugated inner liner and the bottom of the box. DurationRel: 4 and MitigateEffect: Removed the package from the sort, to prevent leakage onto other packages, placed it in a lined hazmat tote and placed it in the hazmat cage for inspection.

DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was placed upright into Hazmat tote.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-18T21:10:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-04
  • City: PORTLAND
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 4, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN2031 had a faulty cap in transit and leaked approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the top and sides of drum, as well as the poly wrap. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GMES) to remediate the impacted site. GMES personnel removed all contaminated poly wrap to inspect the drum. Crews utilized rags and a neutralizing solution to collect the released product from the top and sides of the drum. GMES personnel utilized an 85-gallon open top drum to overpack and contain the damaged 55-gallon drum. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 30-gallon drum. All containers were staged onsite for future disposal.

  • City: SAN LORENZO

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 4, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN1230 was punctured and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Patriot Environmental Services (PES) to remediate the site. PES personnel deployed granular absorbents to the methanol-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. Crews transferred the product into a new 330-gallon tote.

  • Description: On December 1, 2023, two (2) 55-gallon drums of UN3265 were punctured by a forklift and released approximately fifty (50) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the release and worked them in with hand tools. All UN3265-impacted material was containerized in three (3) 55-galon drums. The two (2) damaged 55-gallon drums were overpacked into two (2) 95-gallon overpacks for terminal disposal.

  • Description: On December 1, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN2735 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Enviro Care, Inc. (EC) to remediate the impacted site. EV personnel deployed absorbents to the release and utilized hand tools to remediate the site. The crew containerized the one (1) damaged 55-gallon drum in one (1) 95-gallon overpack. All UN2735-impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and one (1) cubic yard bag for future disposal.

Package was then moved to the HazMat Cage for proper holding and inspection. DescribePack: Package does not show any major failure points, lids on package were seemingly tight, and package appeared to have leaked at the top of the box going downward on a peculiar side. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package did not show any further indication of a leak, however it was kept inside the black tote for monitoring overnight, when we arrived there was no additional liquid beyond what was absorbed into the box.

DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The package was placed into a tote to mitigate any chance of additional spillage.

  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PVS TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: PVS Transportation Driver had to use 3 separate hose conections to deliver product into the customer's tank. When the driver pressurized the trailer a leak developed at the dry-mate connection on the second hose. The connection was leaking for approxiamately 5 minutes in duration before the operater on site notified the driver and the flow was turned off. Floor-dry was used by the customer to absorb the spilled product.

item.title: Report I-2023120041

Report I-2023120041

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-24
  • City: Clermont
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PENN TANK LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: While driver was loading AVJET A at the Buckeye terminal, product began coming out of the vapor tube due to pressure within the tube. Driver shut off the delivery hose and disconnected from the trailer. As he departed the location some product was still leaking from the tube, leaving approximately 55 gallons of product in the basin in the terminal and along the Raceway Road as he left. Cleanup was conducted by the Wayne Township Fire Department and HEPACO.

item.title: Report I-2023120036
item.description:
Report I-2023120036

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-22T18:12:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-21
  • City: Kenner
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: DELTA AIR LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Delta received notification on 11/21/23 of an undeclared event where a UN0276(Cartridges, power device(squib)) shipped undeclared from Atlanta to New Orleans airport. There were five parts in total located in the shipment; one of which was hazmat. The original order for this shipment was for four non-hazmat parts. When packaging this box, the agent used recycled packaging material from a nearby recycling bin. The affected cartridge was intermixed within this bin. When the employee used the recycled packaging material, the cartridge was intermixed and unknowingly placed in the box. Flight#: DL2224 Date: 11/21/2023 AWB: 006-80159914 The event is under investigation to determine root cause and subsequent corrective actions. See the attached pictures.

DescribePack: FAILURE OF PACKAGE CAUSED FROM A LOOSE CAP BECAUSE THE PACKAGE WAS DROPPED OR MISHANDLED. DurationRel: 12 and MitigateEffect: THE REAMINING CONTENTS WERE PLACED IN A SALVAGE DRUM TO AWAIT DISPOSITION.

item.title: Report I-2023120039
item.description:
Report I-2023120039

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-21T18:11:30+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-08
  • City: Laredo
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDEX TRADE NETWORKS
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: ALR Trucking arrived at the FedEx Trade Networks facility carrying cargo from Mexico destined for sortation and subsequent distribution in the U.S. Upon opening the trailer doors, it was discovered that one drum of UN1263 was Ieaking near the chime. Six(6) drums were loaded on one wooden skid(pallet) and were secured with plastic and metal banding and shrink-wrap. There were damaged boards on the loading side of the skid. The drum that was Ieaking had its chime fall between the boards, either during the banding process or during transportation. The constant friction of transportation caused the chime area to buckle into the bottom of the drum. The drums are not UN Specification as required in the regulations. We contacted our emergency spill clean-up vendor. They placed the 7 gallon drum into a larger overpack containment drum. The materials used to clean up the small amount that spilled were placed into a 5-gallon plastic bucket for waste disposal. Please see the accompanying photographs of the load upon arrival and the subsequent mitigation. While we do no have the final figures on the remediation, we believe the cost of the clean-up crew to average around $500 or more, and the disposal of the clean-up material to start at$250.

  • Description: It was reported a spill that occurred inside of a trailer and on the dock in Romulus, MI. The spill consisted of (1) 5 gallon plastic bucket of Plasite 7159 Part A (UN1263), which was punctured by a forklift blade during dock ops, causing 5 ounces to release. The SDS was reviewed with the terminal, who stated they would clean the spill with absorbent and place the contents into a 10 gallon poly drum. The created waste was left onsite for the terminal to manage.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: As our driver was making a pickup at a customer location, the customer was loading their freight into our trailer using a forklift. As they were loading a skid, the operator's forks punctured two steel drums already loaded on our trailer from a previous pickup. The majority of the released material was contained to the trailer floor. A professional spill response contractor was called to the scene to contain and remediate all of the released material and overpacked the damaged drums. All released material was containerized for proper disposal. The package specifications were not able to be obtained.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Pkg was offered at a FedEx Office and appears to have been packed in a carton provided by the location. Pkg contains a gasoline powered power washer with several ounces of gasoline still in the fuel tank of the machine. Pkg was found wet on one side due to the pkg with no orientation arrows required for pkgs containing liquid being loaded on its side. Pkg was removed from the trailer unloading area, placed on a flat cart and taken to the HMPA. Pkg was staged in front of an ajar bay door to reduce the smell of fumes. DescribePack: Loose cap on fuel tank of gasoline powered engine. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Pkg was placed in an upright position and cap was secured to mitigate further release.

DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was immediately placed inside a lined tote to contain the leaking paint.

About 1 gallon spilled from 1 pail onto the trailer floor after the pallet gave out and the pail fell through, causing a puncture. Per the SDS, that the material was to be handled with skin/eye/hand PPE and due to the highly flammable properties would need to be kept away from all ignition sources. The total wasted product, damaged container, and impacted absorbents were contained in a 20gal metal drum and left onsite for the terminal to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023120170
item.description:
Report E-2023120170

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-18T21:10:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-06
  • City: FORT PIERCE
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERIGAS PROPANE, L.P.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Transport driver was loading his truck at Lane 2 at our Pompano Beach Terminal and there was a third party attempting to load at lane 1. The third party was having trouble and asked for help. Our transport driver continued to allow his truck to load, but failed to remain in attendance when he went to help the third party load at lane 1. When our transport driver got back to his truck, he noted that it the gauge read 95%, but he proceeded to fill out his paperwork and headed to Ft. Pierce to unload the propane rather than unloading what he had overfilled back into storage down to the AmeriGas required 85%. When our transport driver arrived in Ft. Pierce at 11:45am, he went to look for a service technician for help on what valves to open. As they walked back to the area that his truck was at (roughly 12:00pm), the pressure relief valves activated to release built up pressure - the gauge at this time was reading well over 95% due to expansion and the ground being a unlevel. Our transport driver states that the release lasted for roughly 5 minutes, but that he was able to unload his transport when it stopped leaking.

  • Description: Waste material was staged onto a pallet with other materials then loaded onto an lngenium truck at the Wastelinq transfer facility, then routed to NSSI for disposal. Upon arrival, operations opened the trailer and found drums that had toppled over while in transit. The container in question had a loose lid and a few ounces of material had spilled onto the floor of the truck. NSSI operations acted immediately and unloaded the truck and placed absorbent on the spill. The used absorbent was removed and drummed for disposal. No signs of spillage beyond the trailer were observed.

  • Description: During a routine inspection within the classification yard, FRA noticed product on the side of car and contacted Tacoma Rail. It appeared that the product was leaking from the manway cover. Tacoma Rail contacted an emergency cleanup/repair contractor to clean the rail car and investigate the cause of the leak. The contractor determined that no manway gasket was found in the lid. They installed a 20" manway nozzle gasket and cleaned the spilled product from the side of the car then released it back to Tacoma Rail. ,

item.title: Report I-2023110029
item.description:
Report I-2023110029

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-21T00:34:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-26
  • City: AZUSA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PACIFIC PETROLEUM CALIFORNIA, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: PPC employee and receiving facility employee were unloading the drums from inside the trailer to a location outside. The employees tried to use a pallet jack but were unable to get it under the pallet. The employees proceeded to take one drum at a time from off of the pallet and move them by dolly. There was no sign or indication that the drum was leaking when the employees were moving the drums. When the receiving facility employee moved the last drum, the bottom of the drum cracked. The crack was a total failure (please see attached photo #1) and all fluid was released quickly inside the trailer. The fluids ran out of the trailer and onto the asphalt where it gathered along the cement curb. Employees worked together and set down absorbent boom and pads to contain the waste from spreading further. Fluids stayed onsite in the immediate area and didn't enter any waterways, public property or roads. Internal response team from the facility cleaned up the spill. Waste materials were then collected and placed into new drums for disposal.
